facts.text: Appellant (accused No. 1) charged along with accused Nos. 2, 3, 5 and 6 with having on or about July 11, 1953, transferred by sale 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of Rs. 1,000 each to Velji Lakhamshi Joshi for Rs. 1,800.

anchor.surface_text: when the offence under s. 7 read with s. 4 thereof was companymitted by the appellant herein. The appellant who was the accused No. 1 before the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrates Court, Bombay, was charged along with the accused Nos. 2, 3, 5 and 6 with having on or about July II, 1953, transferred by sale 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of the Denomination of Rs. 1,000 each to one Velji Lakhamshi Joshi for Rs. 1,800 at the rate of Rs. 180 per numbere and thus companytravened the provisions of s. 4 of the Ordinance

facts.text: Appellant convicted by Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate and sentenced to fine of Rs. 8,000 and in default six months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: This objection was overruled by the learned Presidency Magistrate and the trial ended in the companyviction of the appellant along with the companyaccused of the offence with which they had been charged. The appellant was sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 8,000 and in default suffer six months rigorous imprisonment

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay being Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1955.

facts.text: State of Bombay filed Criminal Revision Application No. 435 of 1955 for enhancement of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay, the respondent herein, also filed an application for enhancement of the sentence, being Criminal Revision Application No. 435 of 1955.

facts.text: Bombay High Court confirmed conviction and sentence on April 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It accordingly companyfirmed the companyviction recorded against the appellant by the learned Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate. In regard to the sentence the High Court saw numberground for enhancing the same and companyfirmed the sentence of fine of Rs. 8,000 and in default six months rigorous imprisonment

facts.text: High Court held that appellant transferred 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of Rs. 1,000 each to Velji Lakhamshi.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the learned Presidency Magistrate in regard to the finding of fact and held that the appellant had in fact transferred by sale 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of Rs. 1,000 each to the possession of Velji Lakhamshi and his act fell within the prohibition enacted in s. 4 of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 134  1   c  of the Constitution. The said application was however dismissed by the High Court with the result that he applied for and obtained from this Court special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940 passed on June 27, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The India and Burma  Emergency Provisions  Act, 1940, was passed on June 27, 1940 , and was an Act to make emergency provisions with respect to Government of India and Burma.

facts.text: Emergency period ended on April 1, 1946 by His Majesty's Order in Council.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1946, was published in the Gazette of India Extraordinary His Majestys Order in Council called The India and Burma  Termination of Emergency  Order, 1946 . By the said order the period of emergency referred to in s. 3 of the India and Burma  Emergency Provisions  Act, 1940, was declared to have ended on April 1, 1946.

facts.text: Appellant contended that the Ordinance lapsed on April 1, 1946 when emergency ended.

anchor.surface_text: The argument which was addressed before us by the learned companynsel for the appellant based on these provisions was  a  that as soon as the declaration that the emergency was at an end was made on April 1, 1946, the original position was restored and the Ordinance in question which had been promulgated in exercise of the emergency powers ipso facto lapsed when the emergency was declared to have ended,

arguments.claim: As soon as the declaration that the emergency was at an end was made on April 1, 1946, the original position was restored and the Ordinance ipso facto lapsed when the emergency was declared to have ended.

anchor.surface_text: The argument which was addressed before us by the learned counsel for the appellant based on these provisions was a that as soon as the declaration that the emergency was at an end was made on April 1, 1946, the original position was restored and the Ordinance in question which had been promulgated in exercise of the emergency powers ipso facto lapsed

court_response_anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Court cannot go behind a declaration of emergency made by the Ordinance-making authority cannot affect this question. The power was

arguments.court_reasoning: Argument ignores that ordinances were equated to Acts; omission of time limit made them perpetual; emergency condition for power exercise only.

arguments.claim: In the alternative, s. 72 of the 9th Sch. of the Government of India Act, 1935, having been restored with effect from April 1, 1946, one must look to its terms as they originally stood to justify the continuance of the ordinance after April 1, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: b that, in the alternative, s. 72. of the 9th Sch. of the Government of India Act, 1935, having been thus restored with effect from April 1, 1946, one must look to its terms as they originally stood to justify the continuance of the ordinance in question after April 1, 1946, whensoever it may have been promulgated.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reading suggested tantamount to retrospective effect to original s.72; no warrant for restoring omitted words retrospectively for duration of prior ordinances.

arguments.claim: Ordinances are temporary even if particular time limit removed, as they are emergency measures.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed in support of this contention on the observations of Vardachariar C. J. in King Emperor v. Benoari Lall Sharma and others Legislation by Ordinance has no doubt been given the same effect as ordinary legislation ... even though it is only temporary, though the particular limit has been removed

court_response_anchor.surface_text: dinances for the peace and good government of British India or any part thereof and any ordinance so made shall have the like force of law as an Act p

arguments.court_reasoning: Observations relate to nature and ambit of ordinance power, not duration post-amendment making it perpetual.

arguments.claim: Exercise of ordinance-making power limited by time during which measure remains in operation, tied to emergency.

anchor.surface_text: Zafrulla Khan J. also had expressed himself to the same effect in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee The legislature can at any time enact a measure ... an Ordinance is necessarily of limited duration, whether under s. 72 or under the terms of the India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act of 1940.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er s. 72 during the period specified in s. 3 of the Act, s. 72 should have effect as if the words ,for the space of number more than six months from i

arguments.court_reasoning: Precedents address general nature; specific amendment omits duration limit, equating to perpetual Acts.

arguments.claim: Every statute with no time limit is a perpetual Act continuing until repealed; applies to ordinance without duration limit post-amendment.

anchor.surface_text: Every statute for which no time is limited is called a perpetual Act, and its duration is prima facie perpetual. It continues in force until it is repealed. Vide Craies on Statute Law, 5th Ed. p. 374 Halsburys Laws of England, Hailsham Ed., Vol. XXXI, p. 511, para. 664.

arguments.claim: Emergency is condition precedent to exercise of ordinance power under s.72, but does not limit duration once promulgated without time words.

anchor.surface_text: The emergency under which the Governor-General was invested with the power to make and promulgate Ordinances ... was the condition of the exercise of such power, by the Governor-General and did not impose any limitation on the duration of the Ordinances thus promulgated.

arguments.claim: Omission of 'for the space of not more than six months' by s.1(3) IBEPA equates ordinances promulgated during emergency period to perpetual Acts of Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the deletion of these words from s. 72 leaving the section to be read as above had the necessary effect of equating the Ordinances which were promulgated between June 27, 1940, and April 1, 1946, with Acts passed by the Indian Legislature without any limitation of time as regards their duration.

arguments.claim: Federal Court in J.K. Gas Plant held that ordinances under amended s.72 have no time limit unless self-imposed or repealed.

anchor.surface_text: This position was considered by the Federal Court in J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. and others v. King Emperor where Spens C. J. observed- These Ordinances were made under the powers conferred on the Governor-General by s. 72 ... are subject to no time limit as regards their existence and validity, unless imposed by the Ordinances themselves, or other amending or repealing legislation.

arguments.claim: No subsequent Ordinance or Act amended or repealed the Ordinance, so it continued in force on July 11, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has not been drawn to any subsequent Ordinance or Act of the Indian Legislature amending or repealing the said Ordinance with the result that it continues to be in force and was in operation on July 11, 1953, the date on which the offence in question was committed by the appellant.

arguments.claim: Adaptation of Laws Order, 1950 recognized continuance of the Ordinance post-April 1, 1946 by including it in Second Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: This position was recognized in the Adaptation of Laws Order, 1950, issued under the Constitution Of India. In the Second Schedule to the said Order were contained several Central Ordinances enacted between 1940 and 1946 including the High Denomination Bank Notes Demonetisation Ordinance, 1946

arguments.claim: Subsequent legislative developments like Jammu and Kashmir Extension of Laws Act, 1956 confirm Ordinance continued in operation.

holdings.text: The High Denomination Bank Notes Demonetisation Ordinance, 1946 (Ordinance No. III of 1946) was in operation on July 11, 1953, the date on which the offence was committed by the appellant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinance promulgated during emergency period under amended s.72 without time limit is perpetual until repealed; no repeal or amendment found; recognized in Adaptation of Laws Order, 1950 and subsequent laws.

holdings.text: Ordinances promulgated under s.72 of the 9th Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, as modified by s.1(3) of the India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940, during the emergency period are equated to Acts of the Legislature without any limitation of time as regards their duration and continue perpetually until repealed.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the deletion of these words from s. 72 leaving the section to be read as above had the necessary effect of equating the Ordinances which were promulgated between June 27, 1940, and April 1, 1946, with Acts passed by the Indian Legislature without any limitation of time as regards their duration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission of 'for the space of not more than six months' removes duration limit, making them perpetual Acts; follows Federal Court in J.K. Gas Plant; distinguished from temporary Acts.

holdings.text: The emergency under s.72 was the condition precedent for the exercise of the power to promulgate ordinances but did not impose any limitation on their duration once promulgated without time limit.

anchor.surface_text: The emergency under which the Governor-General was invested with the power to make and promulgate Ordinances ... was the condition of the exercise of such power, by the Governor-General and did not impose any limitation on the duration of the Ordinances thus promulgated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes condition for power exercise from duration provision; duration determined by substantive s.72 terms, which omitted time limit during emergency.

holdings.text: There is no retrospective restoration of the original terms of s.72 (including six-month limit) to ordinances promulgated during the emergency period after April 1, 1946.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No warrant for retrospective operation of original s.72; duration of prior ordinances governed by amended version without time limit.

holdings.text: The appellant was rightly convicted by both the courts below of the offence under s.7 read with s.4 of the Ordinance and s.109 IPC.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinance in force; factual findings of transfer/sale upheld by High Court and not disturbed; preliminary objection rejected.

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Benoari Lall Sharma and others

anchor.surface_text: King Emperor v. Benoari Lall Sharma and others

precedents.case_name: King Emperor v. Benoari Lall Sharma and others
precedents.cited_proposition: operation of the Ordinance is limited to a period of six months and even now it is only temporary, though the particular limit has been removed, and secondly, it is avowedly the exercise of a special power intended to meet an emergency
precedents.cited_holding: by the very terms of s.72 of the Ninth Schedule to the Constitution Act, the operation of the Ordinance is limited to a period of six months and even now it is only temporary, though the particular limit has been removed, and secondly, it is avowedly the exercise of a special power intended to meet an emergency

anchor.surface_text: King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee

precedents.cited_proposition: exercise of the Ordinance-making power is limited in two ways (1) by the limitation as to the circumstances in which it can be exercised, and (ii) by the limitation as to the time during which any measure so enacted can remain in operation. The existence of an emergency is a condition precedent to the exercise of the power
precedents.cited_holding: The legislature can at any time enact a measure and such measure can remain in force without any limit of time but the exercise of the Ordinance-making power is limited in two ways 1 by the limitation as to the circumstances in which it can be exercised, and ii by the limitation as to the time during which any measure so enacted can remain in operation

precedents.citation: J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. and others v. King Emperor

anchor.surface_text: J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. and others v. King Emperor

precedents.case_name: J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. and others v. King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: Ordinances promulgated under s. 72 during the period specified in s. 3 of the India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940 are subject to no time limit as regards their existence and validity unless imposed by the Ordinances themselves or other amending or repealing legislation
precedents.cited_holding: the clear effect of the words of the Act on s. 72 is that Ordinances promulgated under that subsection during the period specified in s. 3 of the Act are subject to no time limit as regards their existence and validity, unless imposed by the Ordinances themselves, or other amending or repealing legislation
